overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish an adjudication system and procedures to process fireworks infractions. [1] This bill amends and establishes various definitions and penalties for firework offenses, including establishing heightened penalties under certain circumstances. [1] It also establishes various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnics and appropriates funds. [1]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ (HB1483_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [1] The funds are to carry out the purposes of this Act, including to update the judiciary information management system to implement the adjudications process established by section 2 of this Act. [1] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [1]
assumptions_and_methodology: The bill creates a dedicated adjudication system for fireworks infractions, similar to the existing traffic infraction system. [1] Creating a fireworks infractions system will allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases, while also allowing them to prioritize higher-level cases as appropriate. [1] The provided document does not contain specific assumptions or methodology for the fiscal projections beyond the establishment of this new system. [1]
agency_impact: This measure will impact the judiciary by establishing a new adjudication system for fireworks infractions. [1] Funds are appropriated to update the judiciary information management system to implement the new process. [1] The bill also allows a district court to have concurrent jurisdiction to hear and dispose of cases of violation of fireworks infractions by children. [1]
economic_impact: The bill establishes various fines and fees that will generate revenue. [1] These include fines for violations ranging from $200 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) to $5,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt), and permit fees of $25 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) and $110 (HB1483_.HTM.txt). [1] The court shall collect the fines imposed and pay eighty per cent to the county in which the fine was imposed, which shall be expended by the county for law enforcement purposes. [1]

six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill appropriates an unspecified sum from general revenues for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027 to update the judiciary information management system. [1] This measure establishes new sources of revenue through fines and fees. [1] Permit fees include a $25 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fee for consumer fireworks and a $110 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fee for aerial devices. [1] An administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) will be imposed for each fireworks infraction in which judgment is entered in favor of the State. [1] Fines for carriers range from $1,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) for a first offense to $5,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) for a third or subsequent offense. [1] Other fines for violations can be no less than $500 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) for each violation. [1] Any person who violates subsection (a) regarding consumer fireworks prohibitions shall be subject to a $200 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fine. [1] Any person who violates subsection (b) regarding distribution timeframes shall be subject to a $1,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fine. [1] The court shall collect the fines and pay eighty per cent to the county for law enforcement purposes and twenty per cent to the State. [1] These fiscal implications will begin when the Act takes effect on July 1, 2025. [1]
